titleStmt.title: Sannati Z.1 (Stele of Gautamīputra Śrī Sātakarṇi)

supportDesc.support: The inscription is on a limestone stele that also depicts a procession of elephants which, according to J. Varaprasada Rao, signifies the final journey of the dead.

origin.origPlace: Sannati, discovered by J. Varaprasada Rao near the find-spot of SaA1 (the praśasti stele of Gautamīputra Śrī Sātakarṇi)

div.p: This edition is based on Varaprasada Rao 1995. Andrew Ollett, Oskar von Hinüber, and Arlo Griffiths contributed to the reading and interpretation.
We have a portion of a vasantatilaka verse.
The inscription is notable for being among the earliest inscriptions in Sanskrit, and the earliest inscriptions in verse.

lg.l: yas svarggatas samavasṛjya narendralakṣmīṃ puttrottame suta-sahasra-samāna-sāre
rājñāṅ kuja-kuśala-kṣaya-karax ku aṃ ku la

div.p: .... who died after transferring his Royal Majesty to the best of his sons, equal in essence to a thousand sons, the one who destroyed the families of kings ... families ...
